Todd, while the first scenario you portray with the NEAT example sounds r=
ight, I am having trouble understanding the second scenario that you descri=
be.  That is, [0, 0.5, 1 , 1] is the coordinate of a connection, so I am no=
t sure what you mean when you ask if it is "input" first?  Activation trave=
ls down all connections in the same layer simultaneously in the same timest=
ep, and is summed at the target neurons.   So order shouldn't matter, thoug=
h I may be misunderstanding.

One thing that I can answer is that links do =
not have state, though nodes have state.  However, like I said, I may not b=
e understanding the question fully.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "jto=
ddowen" <jtoddowen@...> wrote:
>
> Please correct me if I'm wrong.  My unde=
rstanding of recurrence and
> neuron links in NEAT is that during each time=
step new input data is
> presented to the ANN and travels to the next neuro=
n until ultimately
> reaching the output.  Therefore, using the NEAT struct=
ure at
> http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/neat.html
> <http://www.cs.ucf.edu=
/%7Ekstanley/neat.html>  it would take 3 timesteps
> for activation from in=
put 1 to traverse neurons 16, 269 and then 5,
> although data is also going=
 directly from 1 to 5 (through a direct link)
> in one step.
> 
> If the ab=
ove is correct, how do the HyperNEAT timesteps work?  Using the
> model fro=
m http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html
> <http://eplex.cs.u=
cf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html%20>  does [0, 0.5,
> 1 , 1] get input, =
then [0.5, 0, 1, 0.5] next?  If so, it would seem to
> me the order you tra=
versed the points in the substrate would affect the
> output.  Or, do you k=
eep the "state" of each link activation stored
> separately from one input =
substrate to another (one checkerboard play to
> another); in other words, =
are you keeping (4096 + 64) "states" for each
> timestep?
> 
> --Todd
>
